pageContext.claim: “You don't need a Constitutional amendment for birthright citizenship. I believe that you can have a simple vote in Congress, or it's even possible, in my opinion -- this is after meeting with some very talented legal scholars -- that you can do it through an executive order.”
pageContext.analysis: The Justice Department's official position from 1995 indicates birthright citizenship cannot be erased either with an act of Congress or an executive order. Plus, the Supreme Court's decision in Wong Kim Ark and Plyler strongly suggests the birthright-citizenship guarantee extends to undocumented immigrants' children.
